en: Germans love rich, hearty cuisine, though each area of Germany has its own definition of what a traditional meal looks like.
Pork is the most consumed meat in Germany, according to the German Food Guide.
Schweinshaxe (braised pork hock) and Saumagen (pork stomach) are a couple of traditional pork dishes in Germany.
Bratwurst, a form of sausage, is closely associated with German food and culture.
Cabbage, beets, and turnips are commonly added into meals, as they are native to the region, and potatoes and sauerkraut are also stars of German cuisine.
Beer in Germany is the most popular alcoholic beverage, and the country is known as the birthplace of a number of beer varieties, including Pilsner, Weizenbier (wheat beer) and Alt.
Germans have made tremendous contributions to classical music and the traditions of famous German or Austrian composers such as Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Richard Wagner.
German Unification Day on October 3 marks the reuniting of East and West Germany and is the only federal holiday.
The German tradition Oktoberfest started in 1810, with the wedding of Crown Prince Ludwig of Bavaria to Princess Therese von Sachsen-Hildburghausen, according to the city of Munich.

The first use of the modern word “China” in the West was in 1555, from the Persian Cin (چین). This use was derived from the Chinese Qín, after the First Emperor Qin Shi Huangdi of the Qin Dynasty, which first unified China under a single Emperor in 221BC.
Before the Communists took control of China in 1949, the country had five time zones. Today, China only has one time zone: Beijing time (UTC +8).
Fortune cookies have never been a Chinese custom. It was a modification of a traditional 19th century Japanese cookie, which was first popularized in San Francisco by Makota Hagiwara.
Founded in 1903 by German settlers, Tsingtao Beer accounts for over 50% of China’s beer exports (but only has 15% of domestic market share).
Cars in China drive on the left side of the road since it was founded as a British colony. However, drivers in mainland China drive on the right side.
Сricket fighting is still a popular pastime for many Chinese kids and adults. It was particularly popular in Macau, where people bet on cricket fights.

The Chinese have been flying kites for nearly three thousand years. Legend has it that it was invented by two 5th century BC philosophers, Lu Ban and Mozi, in China, where kite materials were available: silk fabric (for sail and line) and bamboo for a light, sturdy frame.
Ping pong (table tennis) is the most popular amateur recreational sport in China, with about 300 million players.
Soccer (football)—the most popular sport in England—was invented in China over two thousand years ago, during the Han Dynasty, when it was called “cuju” (or “kick ball”).
The Chinese invented noodles, which they’ve been eating for at least 4,000 years, according to radiocarbon dating of ancient noodles discovered near the Yellow River in 2005.

In ancient China, the process of making silk making was a closely guarded secret  punishable by the death penalty. The Romans - who were great admirers of silk, believed that the fabric was taken from trees.
Drinking tea is widely considered to have started first in China, which has the earliest surviving records of tea drinking dating back to the first millennium BC.
Balloons - known as Kongming lanterns, were airborne lanterns that were used for military signaling.
More than 1 in 3 Chinese people believe in fortune telling.

“Year of the Golden Pig”, considered an auspicious year that is also associated with fertility. 2007 was the first year in six decades that the “Year of the Pig” was astrologically associated with “gold”.
The number 4 is the unluckiest Chinese number because it sounds like the word for “death”. Many buildings in China don’t have a 4th floor.
The number 8 is the luckiest Chinese number because it sounds like the word for “wealth”. 88 is considered particularly lucky because it symbolized the “double happiness” characters.
The Beijing Olympic opening ceremony started exactly at 8 seconds and 8 minutes past 8pm on August 8, 2008. What confirms the love for the number 8.
9,000 Chinese couples got married on August 8, 2008 in Beijing, more than doubling the previous single-day marriage record.
At a 2010 government auction, a car license plate featuring the lucky number 8 was sold for a record-breaking 1.314 million yuan (US$197,540).
Senior Chinese politicians are “addicted” to dyeing their hair black. They generally only allow their hair to turn white after they retire (or if they’re sent to jail).
About 50 of China’s most powerful men have a red phone, called the “red machine” -  on their desks.
China is officially an atheist state with one of the lowest percentages in the world of people who consider themselves religious.
Chinese celebrate October 1 as National Day in honor of the founding of the People’s Republic of China.
China Spring Festival (the celebration of Chinese New Year, late-January to mid-February depending on Lunar calendar)
March 12 is the Day of Planting Trees in China
In China, "Lantern Festival" is the most profitable for selling candles and fireworks.
Residents of Germany are the champions of Europe in terms of the number of days off and holidays. Up to fifteen days of holiday.
During the night from April 30 to May 1 Germany celebrates the Sabbat of the Witches.
In Germany, in Cologne, main procession of buffoons is visited by more than a million tourists.
January 21 in Germany is the "Day of training pants." On this day, everyone goes around wearing sports pants.
In the Sudanese Latuka tribe (Africa), when a man wants to marry a woman, he kidnaps her. And if dad agrees, he beats the suitor as a sign of his acceptance of the union.
Khweta Ceremony. When they are of age, boys are sent to spend several days or weeks in a circumcision lodge during winter, where they’re put through dangerous tests and rituals, and circumcision.
Lobola in Southern African tradition is when the families of a bride and a groom negotiate how much the groom must pay for the bride. All negotiations must be done in writing.
In Africa, men spit on newborns and say they are bad in the belief that if they praise a baby, it will be cursed.
Maasai warriors (Africa) will spit in their hands before shaking the hand of an elder.
In order to prove their manhood in the Ethiopian Hamer tribe (in Africa), young boys must run, jump and land on the back of a bull before then attempting to run across the backs of several bulls.
The Ahaggaren Tuaregs of Algeria (Africa) are part of a larger group of Berber-speaking Tuaregs. In their culture, the men wear veils almost all the time.
Each wife of Gio tribe (Africa) has her own small house that she lives in with her children until they are old enough to move out. The children never live with their fathers.
In the Southwestern Congo, the Suku tribe (Africa) honors ancestors and elders, when they die, with a ceremony held in the clearing of a forest. Here, gifts and offerings are brought.

When male children reach age of 5 in the Northern Angolan Songo (Africa) tribe, they are sent to live with their uncles on their mother’s side. This is because chiefs inherit their position through matrilineal lines.
Pokot people (Africa). The number of women a man can marry is determined by how many cows he has.
The Maasai people of Kenya and Tanzania (Africa) protect wild animals and treat them as clan members.
The Himba people of Northern Namibia (Africa) cover their skin with a mixture of butter fat and ochre - a natural earth pigment containing iron oxide - to protect themselves from the sun.
In Sharo (Africa) if two young men want to marry the same woman, they compete for her by beating one another. The one not showing pain signs can take the wife.
Tradition of Malawi tribes in Africa. When a person dies, one family takes the body into the woods, slits the throat, and forces water through the body to cleanse it.
When a girl becomes a teenager in the Surma tribe of Southern Sudan (Africa), she has her bottom teeth removed to make space for a lip plate, which is increased in size annually.
Padaung are rings that girls wear in some tribes of Africa.
Shampooing is an Indian concept. From Sanskrit word "champs" - means to massage. So the Indians are happy to wash their hair.
India has a spa just for elephants. Elephants receive baths, massages and even food at the Punnathoor Cotta Elephant Yard Rejuvenation Centre in Kerala.
India was the first country to develop extraction and purifying techniques of sugar. Therefore, Indians traditionally prepare a variety of sweets.
Freddie Mercury and Ben Kingsley are both of Indian descent. The films and songs of these people are very popular in their historical homeland in India.

Earlier known as Moksha Patamu, the game was initially invented as a moral lesson about karma to be taught to children. It was later commercialized and has become one of the most popular board games in the world.
India is known for its traditional large assortment of dishes and its liberal use of herbs and spices. Cooking styles vary from region to region.
There is a wide array of breads served with meals in India, including naan, a leavened, oven-baked flatbread, and bhatoora, a fried, fluffy flatbread common in North India.
Much of Indian food is eaten with fingers or bread used as utensils. This is not because of the lack of dishes, but because of religion.

The major classical dance traditions of Indians - Bharata Natyam, Kathak, Odissi, Manipuri, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam and Kathakali - draw on themes from mythology and literature and have rigid presentation rules.
The traditional clothing for Indian men is the dhoti, an unstitched piece of cloth that is tied around the waist and legs.
Lamb and chicken are common in main dishes for non-vegetarians in India. They do not eat beef, because cows are a sacred animal.
The Nehru jacket is a shorter version of a sherwani in Indian.
Diwali" is the largest and most important holiday in India.
A French meal usually includes bread (long, crusty baguettes are popular), and cheese.
Boeuf bourguignon" stewed meat with vegetables is the main dish of French cuisine.
The French invented the crepe and they are still sold all over the place in France, even at street vendor carts. It is a traditional French dessert
Every one of France's 22 regions has its own traditional dress.
French people tend to be private, polite, and the handshake is the common form of greeting. Some French use kissing on the cheek as a greeting.
French believe that number of flowers should only be given in even numbers.
In France is extremely rude to be more than 10 minutes late for a meal without calling to explain the delay.
France is the first country in the world to prohibit supermarkets from disposing or destroying unsold products.
At least 40 percent of the music on private radio stations must be of French origin. Such laws are in France.
France produces nearly a billion tons of cheese a year in around 1,200 different varieties. Cheese is the main appetizer for wine in France.
In France, April 1, celebrate "Fool's Day", on this day you can paste paper fish on your back. This tradition goes back to the 14th century.
French eat around 30,000 tonnes of snails a year
It is against the law to carry live snails on a high-speed train in France without their own tickets.
Frog paws are considered to be delicacies in France. 1 frog is cheaper than 1 chicken.
Italians claim to have taught the rest of Europe how to cook. Italy is responsible for introducing ice cream to the world
When McDonald's opened in 1986 in Rome, food purists outside the restaurant gave away free spaghetti to remind people of their culinary heritage.
Italian Pizza is traditional in Italy, it has gained its popularity even before the people of Naples.
Soccer fans in Italy traditionally are called "Tifosi", meaning “carriers of typhus.” Italian soccer fans are known for their rowdy behavior and lack of inhibition.
In Italy each September in even-numbered years town’s main piazza becomes a life-sized chess board.
Many people in Italy celebrate Christmas Eve with a huge feast, often featuring seafood.
The Sardinian Island (Italy) is famous for its “witches” who make health potions for local people. The “witches” are usually women.
Italian citizens who are 18 years old can vote for the lower house in the Chamber of Deputies. Citizens who 25 years old can vote for the 315 members of the upper house, the Senate.
Many single Italian people live at home until their 30s, even if they have a job. The Italian family stands at the heart of Italian society.
In Italy people used to eat pasta with sugar, without even adding tomato sauce.
In central Italy, there is a fountain that flows red wine 24-hours a day. It is free to everyone. It is loved by true connoisseurs of wine.
For Italians, food is not just food, it's life.
The Italian dish of Colombo is sweet bread in the form of a dove. Traditional food for Easter.
One Italian tradition is to throw out unnecessary things from the window for the New Year. Enter New Year with new things and opportunities!
In some regions of Italy it is considered obligatory to eat twelve grapes under the chiming clock, which symbolize the 12 months of the coming year.
In Rome (Italy) it is believed that the happy ones in the upcoming year will be the ones, who on New Year's night will jump from the bridge into the waters of the Tiber River.
In Italy it is not recommended to be married in May, because everyone knows that in this month there is one unlucky day, but problem is - no one knows which day it is....
In contrast to other countries, in Britain, April 1st is the Jokes day only until noon - after noon all jokes are considered a manner of bad tone.
A bank holiday in Britan is a state holiday, when banks and many other businesses are closed for a day. Bank holidays are indicated in the charter or proclaimed by royal decree.
In Britan bog snorkelling - is the act of swimming using a snorkel. People race each other in a 120ft trench filled with mud.
In Britan 'Guy Fawkes Day' also known as 'Bonfire Night', marks the November 5, 1605, when Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament.
British humor is so specific that in order to understand it you need to try. This is the only country with traditional humor known throughout the world.
In Britan it was believed that women were impure for six weeks after giving birth, all Jewish mothers went to the Temple for the ceremony called the Purification.
In Britan sailors are often reluctant to set sail on Candlemas Day, believing that any voyage begun then will end in disaster.
Advent" is not widely celebrated in England, its celebration actually originated in Germany, although in the church calendar Advent is the official start of the run up to Christmas.
In England Boxing Day celebrated on December 26th, is traditionally a time to give gifts to tradesmen, servants, and friends.
In England Christmas puddings or plum puddings are a very rich, dark pudding made with all sorts of dried fruits, nuts, spices, black treacle and lots of sherry or brandy.
English national dress unfortunately is not really there. There is no traditional national dress as such.
The British Gentleman is a male image formed in the Victorian era. Initially, the word "gentleman" meant a man of noble birth.
In England, Cricket is a national game. Cricket is a bat and ball sport.
Tea - an integral part of the life of the British, like potatoes or bread. There is even a saying: "Seven cups of tea will help wake up, nine cups will help fall asleep.
In England, Fish&Chips is a popular fast food. This food is very cheap and nutritious.
In England, It is not customary for men to kiss the hand of a lady when greeting
In England, despite the fact that it is absolutely not recommended to be late, it is not customary to come to meetings earlier in England.
England tradition "five-o’clock tea", means the most direct, to drink tea in the period from 16 to 18.
One of the most important unspoken rules in Britain: at the table it is not polite to whisper or secret with a neighbor. The conversation should be common to everyone.
First of all, the British value their personal space. While in France it is accepted to kiss at a meeting. Therefore, the French feel uneasy in Britain.
Traditionally, there is no gender discrimination in the UK. Work a woman will have the same as a man, without any indulgence.
Britain's most ardent football fans, during the matches the whole country (without exaggeration!) Is waiting for the outcome of the game.
Every city, even the smallest town in the UK, has its own theater. Homeland of Shakespeare can not help but love the theater.
The Hermitage, in Russia is home to around 70 cats, which guard its treasures against rodents. The tradition dates back to a 1745 decree of Empress Elizabeth.
Subbotnik" in Russia is a day when residents of Russian cities volunteer to sweep up and tidy the streets. It started after the revolution but still happens today.
The icicles hanging from the gutters in Russia in winter are so enormous that the pavements below are cordoned off. They are knocked down by specialized personnel.
In Russia, there is a bronze sculpture of a dog with a shiny nose at Ploshchad Revolutsii metro station - it is shiny because it's good luck to touch it.
In Russia, frozen chicken's foot soup (kholodets) is a traditional delicacy.
In Russia, people like cloakrooms. Therefore they are practical everywhere.
In Russia, Giving flowers to residents can be a delicate point of etiquette. You should always make sure you give them in odd numbers, unless going to a funeral, when even numbers are the rule.
In Russia, next to the bridge to reach the Peter and Paul Fortress, be a hare It's considered good luck to hit it with a coin.
In Russia, word "vodka" derives for the word "voda", which means "water".
In Russia, lock trees can be found in Moscow - couples place them here to prove their love.
In Russia, It's considered ok unless the temperature drops below -20C you do not need to wear a hat with a fur hat.
In Russia, Foreigners pay a higher entrance fee at many tourist sites. It is done for Russians to experience more of their history, and not to make more money on tourists
In Russia, on Baikal lake there is a shaman stone, where shamanistic rites are held.
In Russia, Western leaders are not welcome in at least one airport duty free shop.
In Russia there are people called “walruses” – believers in the therapeutic effects of freezing water. They gather beside the Peter and Paul Fortress to bathe in winter.
In Russia, in St Petersburg there is a pair of 15th-century sphinxes from Egypt. You should make a wish looking into the eyes of the Sphinx during 10 minutes.
In Russia, on a carnival feast "Maslenitsa", a scarecrow is burned and people dance around it. This symbolizes the beginning of spring after a cold winter.
In Russia, "Ilyin Day" is celebrated on August 2. It is when the bathing season ends. On this day the girls send wreaths on the river. And in the evening people dance and jump over the fire.
In Russia, Leshiy is the rightful owner of every forest. According to many beliefs, cursed dead people become Leshiy. Therefore, in Russia, forests are treated with care and respect.

In Russia, on April 1, people celebrate the day of the Boggart. If it lives in the house, then there is always comfort. Another April 1 celebration is the day of Fools, on this day you can play tricks on others.
In Russia, Fistfights were arranged in the winter during the Christmas season on Maslenitsa (Shrovetide). Two villages or residents of the opposite ends of one large village could fight each other.
In Russia, Bread wine is a strong alcoholic drink that ancestors drank before the invention of vodka. You can not get it in shops, but it is often made at home.
In Russia, Ivan-tea (willow herb) is a national tea. In ancient times, this tea was a big competition to Ceylon tea.
In Russia, going to the bathhouse happens before an important event. Bath rejuvenates and gives strength.
In Russia, Matryoshka is a traditional Russian souvenir. Matryoshka is a Russian wooden toy in the form of a painted doll, inside of which there are similar dolls of smaller size.
In Russia, Caviar or ikra, is traditionally made from the eggs of sturgeon found in the Black Sea or Caspian Sea. It is often served on dark, crusty bread or with pancakes.
In Russia, Pancakes are eaten mostly during Maslenitsa (Shrovetide), but usually they are in demand too. Pancakes can be served both with sweet fillings, and with meat or caviar.
In Russia, wearing a beard is normal. The beard shows wisdom and fidelity to ancestors.
In Russia, collecting badges and stamps, is a great tradition. There is even a special priority of things that can be sold expensively or exchanged.
When Americans attend sports events it's often not enough to simply show up and take their seats. They need to arrive hours in advance to properly drink beer and eat a hot dog.
The vast majority of Super Bowl spectators are Americans, and they eagerly await breaks in the big game to see which commercials wow them the most.
In the US peple often flock to farms in order to attend fall festivals. Families participate in activities like picking pumpkins, walking through corn mazes, sampling cider.
In the US during Halloween people exchange various sweets, but some of these traditions involve children going door-to-door asking for candy with the words: "Trick or treat!".
In the United States on the day of Thanksgiving family circle gathers together and thank God for the food. Turkey is served.
A relatively new tradition in the United States is Black Friday. On this day people carry out purchases at night at very large discounts.
In the US, each year, groundhogs around the country are paraded out to predict how many more weeks before spring comes.
In the US, jeans and cowboy hats were labour clothes, but now they are positioned as traditional.
In the US, hamburgers, hot dogs, potato chips, are very popular, and are well known all over the world too.
In the US, Apple pie is considered traditional, because of the ease of cooking and excellent quality.
In the US, Independence Day celebrated at 4th of July. On this day marches of performances, dances, songs, and in the evening an unforgettable firework appear on the streets
In the US, there is taditional competition "Cherry Pit Spitting" - who spits cherry farther
Ostriches were first brought to the US in the 1880s, and ostrich-riding races appeared in several states across the country.
In the US, every September, people in Marlington have a Roadkill Cook-off, where you can try such delights as biscuits covered in squirrel gravy, teriyaki-marinated bear or deer sausage.
The National Hollerin’ Contest, North Carolina (United States), is a competition of people who shout louder.
American football, known in the the US as simply "football," now attracts more television viewers than any other sports and is considered to be the most popular sport in the United States.
Lacrosse is a team sport of American and Canadian Native origin and is the fastest growing sport in the United States. Lacrosse is most popular in the East Coast area.
Speed eating (hamburgers, hot dogs, pizza) is one of the frequent traditional competitions in the United States.
In the US, there is a tradition to show a bare ass to the passengers of a passing train.
In Spain, on birthdays piñatas are broken with a stick, and lots of different sweets fly out
For girls in Spain, the 15th birthday signifies a coming of age. This selebrate named "Quinceañera". Common Quinceañera gifts include tiaras, bracelets, and earrings.
In Spanish-speaking countries, Carnival celebrations are held between late January to early March, the time leading up to great Lent.

Devout Catholics in Mexico make a pilgrimage to the Basilica de Guadalupe in Mexico City every year on December 12th. The date commemorates the appearance of the Virgin Mary to the Indian Juan Diego in 1531.

Dia de la Independencia (Mexican Independence Day) falls on September 16th, but begins the night before when the President of Mexico rings the bell at the National Palace in Mexico City, and shouts “Viva México!”

San Judas Tadeo (St. Jude Thaddeus) is known as the Saint of Lost Causes. On the 28th day of every month, people gather at San Hipólito Church, the church dedicated to St. Jude in downtown Mexico City.
Originally Spanish Christmas traditions, "Posadas" are now commonly held in Mexico and Guatemala. In Mexico, people hold candles and sing songs.
The Spanish Christmas tradition features a parade, Cabalgata de los Reyes, where the Three Kings arrive on horseback (camel) or on decorated floats, and throw treats and presents to the children.
In Hispanic cultures, it’s important to remember family members and friends who have passed. Día de los Muertos is Art related to the holiday depicts skeletons enjoying life on the other side.
A Siesta, or afternoon nap/rest (between 2 p.m. and 5 p.m.) is one of the classic Spanish traditions in Hispanic countries.
Spanish people believe that evil eye can be cured by rubbing around the eye socket with an umbilical cord.
Castels are people's towers. The holiday of the church is a kind of unusual competition, which has become a real attraction of Spain.
Spanish Tomato (La Tomatina) is a real tomato battle. After a special signal, several trucks loaded with ripe tomatoes enter the main square of the city, which serve as tools for the battle.
Egg-floury war in the city of Ibi (Spain). Use flour and raw eggs as a weapon. Before the battle, men are divided into two groups - married and not married.
During the annual holiday of San Blas in Casayilla (Spain), local residents throw down the turkey from the churchs belltower, and the crowd gathered below tries to catch it.
Holiday of Kolacho (Spain). A man in a devil costume (kolacho) walks through the village. He jumps above little children thus driving away illnesses and troubles from their life.
Day of the Goose (Spain). Through the territory of the port a rope with a dead goose is placed. People swim on boats to the goose and jump out of the boat to grab the goose by the head.
Summer New Year (Spain) happens in the first week of August. It was created for those who missed it in the winter.

The sweetest holiday in San Sebastian (Spain) - the battle where more than 300 kilograms of desserts are used, with the fighters divided into age groups throwing desserts at one another. The winner is the cleanest.
On the islands of Polynesia, the newlyweds must spend their wedding night in a circle of friends, not alone with each other.

Muslims in the Indian state of Maharashtra drop the newborn babies from the wall of the temple at a height of 15 meters. Below, of course, pull the fabric. In their opinion, this strengthens the health of the child.
In Tibet, in the Ganden monastery, the body of the deceased is dismembered into parts and placed on the slopes of the mountain, so that it returns to the world cycle of natural substances.
In North Kamchatka, the landlady tries to seduce guest who appears in the village. If a guest enters into an intimate relationship with her, he thereby honors the family.

In the Satere Mawe tribe (Brazil) every young man undergoes a special ritual - he puts on his hand a glove full of parapet ants for 11 hours, whose bite is 30 times more painful than the bite of a wasp.
In Sweden they love "fika" (from the word "coffee", with syllables exchanged). Skipping a fika at work is a bad tone, for it's not a job that can be postponed.

In Sweden, they fear flu and colds. Swedish medicine does not believe that the blame for the illness should be put on breeze or cold. Every autumn there are queues for vaccination in clinics, because bacteria is to blame.
Swedes are not ashamed of natural needs. If a Swede wanted to warm up at the bus stop: to squat or stretch - he wont be embarrassed by the public to do the exercises.
Political correctness in Sweden is off scale. The genre of anecdotes and jokes is unpopular. Not to mention to publicly joke on the representatives of some social group or country.

In Karakha Pujan (India), the father must bathe the newborn son in boiling milk. The ritual is usually held in Hindu temples. The whole ceremony is accompanied by the reading of mantras by Hindu priests.

It is common for Sweden to leave their children sleeping on the street. Swedish parents believe that being accustomed to cold temperatures will temper their children and protect them from many diseases.
In Bali, Indonesia, there is a tradition that infants under three months of age are forbidden to touch the ground. All the first three months of life, children spend in the hands of family members.
In the culture of Japan, the umbilical cord is of great importance. It is so great that mothers here store the umbilical cord of their children in special boxes called Kotobuki Bako.
In Armenia when the child has his first tooth, baby is put on the table where are different items placed. The first object to which the baby is drawn will predetermine his future.
Japanese festival Nakizumo organizes contests for crying among children. Two sumo wrestlers enter the ring, each of them is given the child. The first who makes a baby cry is considered the winner.
In Bulgaria after the child is complimented he receives a real spit. This is a kind of protection ceremony so that no one can jinx the child.
In Turkey, a man can not have a second wife until he presents gold jewelry to his lady for at least $ 10,000. Thus, he confirms the ability to feed two wives.
In Kenya, a young man after the wedding should wear one month's women's clothing and carry out women's duties. Then he will remember for a lifetime that being a woman is not so easy.
Australian aboriginal warriors, instead of the usual handshake, demonstrate friendliness in a slightly different way - namely by touching a penis of another person
Any self-respecting Andalusian before his wedding must jump from the cliff head down. According to the ancient customs of Andalusia, it is believed that a man can marry only with a strong skull.
Foot bandaging is the old Chinese tradition that takes from the X century. Girls from the earliest age of 5-6 years pulled their feet with bandages to prevent growth of their feet.
The Chinese believe that you can not give live flowers. It is a symbol of death - "they will soon wither". But artificial - it is always possible. "They are eternal.
In Thailand, the fork is not put in the mouth. A fork is used to put food in a spoon and eat from it.
In Taiwan there is an unusual tradition - to striptease at a funeral. It is done for the deceased and those who came to say goodbye.
In Sweden they like to eat fish with smell. Even a festival of fermented herring is held. The disgusting smell of the dish is compensated by its magical, according to the Swedes, taste.
Japanese funeral tradition: the chopsticks in an upright position are left near the bed of a recently deceased relative.
In Japan people eat dolphins. They make soup, prepare kusiyaki (Japanese shishkebab), even eat raw. Dolphins have quite a tasty meat, with a distinct taste, and quite unlike the fish.
In Japan, restaurant tips are not accepted. It is believed that as long as the customer pays for the service full price, he remains with the seller on an equal footing.
Japanese have a very unusual position towards pornography. Some time before in all hotels there was even a tv channel with porno
In Japanese families it is absolutely normal, when brother and sister do not talk to each other at all, and do not even know each other's mobile phone numbers.
The Japanese people are very clean, but, no matter how many members in the family, everyone took bath without changing the water. However, before that everyone takes a shower.
To come to work on time in Japan is considered bad form. You have to be at least half an hour early.
In Japan, you can see vases with umbrellas on the streets. If it starts to rain, you can take any, and then, when the rain ends, put it in the nearest vase.
On Japanese streets, you will not see garbage cans. All Japanese garbage is taken home, and then sorted into four types: glass, burned, processed and non-burning waste.
There are no guest workers in Japan. According to local legislation, the minimum wage of a foreign worker exceeds the Japanese average salary.
In cities in northern Japan, all the sidewalks are heated in winter, so there is no ice. Everyone heats their house on their own.
In Japan, extremely honest people. A lost wallet with a probability of 90% can be found in the lost property office.
In Japan, there is the death penalty. Most executions are personally attended by the Minister of Justice.
In Australia. Walk through the streets at midnight and drum, that there are forces, on pots and frying pans. And you will not have anything for it.
In Brazil. To scare off evil spirits you need to wear white clothes.
Goddess of water in Yemange (on the island of Mystic) loves gifts, especially flowers. So throw a couple of flowers into the water, if they come back - then she did not accept the gift.
In Chile, at midnight for the new year, you must eat a spoonful of lentils, then your year will be filled with work and money.
In Colombia, For a new year, walk around the block with an empty suitcase, so that the year is filled with travel.

In Ecuador. A scarecrow or a doll is burned, as a symbol of farewell to the old year and greetings of the new. This tradition is similar to the Russian one, where a scarecrow is burned for farewell to the winter.

In El Salvador. Exactly at midnight for the new year, break the egg into a glass and leave it on the windowsill until morning. What figure will be in the morning in a glass, then waits for you in the new year.
In Finland. On the strange tradition of throwing molten lead in cold water, and after looking at the patterns, thereby predicting their own destiny.

In Guatemala, at midnight, on New Year's Eve, take 12 coins, then go out into the street and throw them behind your back, standing on the opposite side of the street. This tradition brings happiness to the next year.

In the Philippines, there is a tradition to open all doors, cabinets, drawers and windows, and then, right after midnight of the New Year, run through the house and close them. It is done to scare off evil spirits
In Puerto Rico at midnight before New Year people pour out water from buckets and pots in front of the doorsteps.
In Russia, at the New Year, write your wish on a piece of paper, burn it, and throw the ash into a glass of champagne, then drink the contents before time reaches 00:01. And your wish will come true.
On New Years day in Turkey, people throw pomegranates out of the windows and onto the streets. The more it breaks, the more generous the year will be.
In Venezuela at the New Years day - wear yellow underwear. For good luck.
In Argentina, at the New Years day, new pink clothes are put on to attract love.
In Brazil, there is the tradition of jumping over the waves. You need to jump over 7 waves in a row, so that luck would come.
In the United States at Сhristmas, people hang socks by the fireplace, so that Santa Claus would put gifts in them.
In Japan if you are apprehended by police for something serious, they have the right to arrest you for 30 days, not letting even a lawyer inside.
